articles.headline: A Boot Camp to Prepare for Retirement
articles.snippet: Eight drills to determine if your finances are healthy enough for you stop working  and to help get them on track if they’re not.
articles.abstract: Eight drills to determine if your finances are healthy enough for you stop working  and to help get them on track if they’re not.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marcia Tillotson and Joy Kenefick aren’t your typical drill sergeants.

articles.headline: Obama Shifts Tone on Gates After Mulling Debate
articles.snippet: President Obama’s improvised handling of a racial debate underscored the challenges facing a leader who has tried to emphasize similarities over differences.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s improvised handling of a racial debate underscored the challenges facing a leader who has tried to emphasize similarities over differences.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama tried Friday to defuse a volatile national debate over the arrest of a black Harvard University professor as he acknowledged that his own comments had inflamed tensions and insisted he had not meant to malign the arresting officer.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: A Little Too Responsible? That’ll Cost You
articles.snippet: The CIT Group’s earlier decision to wander into fewer risky bets has now made it more likely to fail.
articles.abstract: The CIT Group’s earlier decision to wander into fewer risky bets has now made it more likely to fail.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We are the poster child for the credit crisis,” said Jeffrey M. Peek, flashing a tight, pained smile.

articles.headline: Bush Weighed Using Military in Arrests
articles.snippet: Some advisers to President George W. Bush, including Dick Cheney, argued in 2002 for using the military to sweep up terrorism suspects on domestic soil.
articles.abstract: Some advisers to President George W. Bush, including Dick Cheney, argued in 2002 for using the military to sweep up terrorism suspects on domestic soil.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Top Bush administration officials in 2002 debated testing the Constitution by sending American troops into the suburbs of Buffalo to arrest a group of men suspected of plotting with Al Qaeda, according to former administration officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and David Johnston

articles.headline: As Officers Face Heated Words, Their Tactics Vary
articles.snippet: The issue of an officer’s tolerance lies at the heart of the dispute surrounding the arrest of a professor.
articles.abstract: The issue of an officer’s tolerance lies at the heart of the dispute surrounding the arrest of a professor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Police departments issue their officers Kevlar vests to stop bullets, and thick helmets and even shields to protect them from bottles and bricks. But there is nothing in the equipment room to give an officer thicker skin.
articles.byline: By Michael Wilson and Solomon Moore

articles.headline: Questions for a Custodian After Scams Hit I.R.A.’s
articles.snippet: Ponzi schemes drained more than $1 billion from retirement accounts with a company called Fiserv, but its role in protecting clients is unclear.
articles.abstract: Ponzi schemes drained more than $1 billion from retirement accounts with a company called Fiserv, but its role in protecting clients is unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three unrelated Ponzi schemes, including Bernard L. Madoff’s, erased more than $1 billion from hundreds of individual retirement accounts set up through a single financial company.

articles.headline: Store From Middle America Opens an Outlet in Midtown
articles.snippet: J. C. Penney is the latest national retailer to take on the competitive and quirky Manhattan market.
articles.abstract: J. C. Penney is the latest national retailer to take on the competitive and quirky Manhattan market.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. C. Penney, the middle American department store, is suddenly in the middle of Manhattan. This week, the value-priced chain quietly opened its first store in the city, in Midtown  a mere falafel cart or two away from its rival Macy’s. The grand opening is July 31.

articles.headline: Iraq Veterans Find Afghan Enemy Even Bolder
articles.snippet: Marines are bracing for a fight against guerrillas who are surprisingly proficient at tactics the Marines themselves learned in infantry school.
articles.abstract: Marines are bracing for a fight against guerrillas who are surprisingly proficient at tactics the Marines themselves learned in infantry school.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAWA, Afghanistan  In three combat tours in Anbar Province, Marine Sgt. Jacob Tambunga fought the deadliest insurgents in Iraq.

articles.headline: Partisan or Not, a Tough Course on Health Care
articles.snippet: President Obama is under growing pressure to choose between wooing a small band of Republicans or struggling to rally his party to get the job done.
articles.abstract: President Obama is under growing pressure to choose between wooing a small band of Republicans or struggling to rally his party to get the job done.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The decision by Senate Democratic leaders last week to devote more time to winning Republican support for a health care overhaul has allowed President Obama to keep alive the possibility of bipartisanship on one of the most contentious issues on his agenda.

articles.headline: Antitrust Chief Hits Resistance in Crackdown
articles.snippet: Christine A. Varney, and some senior lawmakers, are preparing to rein in several major industries but are finding resistance from Obama administration officials.
articles.abstract: Christine A. Varney, and some senior lawmakers, are preparing to rein in several major industries but are finding resistance from Obama administration officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s top antitrust official and some senior Democratic lawmakers are preparing to rein in a host of major industries, including airline and railroad giants, moving so aggressively that they are finding some resistance from officials within the administration.

articles.headline: An Abortion Battle, Fought to the Death
articles.snippet: What thousands could not achieve in three decades of relentless protest, a gunman accomplished on May 31 when he shot Dr. George R. Tiller in the head.
articles.abstract: What thousands could not achieve in three decades of relentless protest, a gunman accomplished on May 31 when he shot Dr. George R. Tiller in the head.
articles.lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan.  It did not take long for anti-abortion leaders to realize that George R. Tiller was more formidable than other doctors they had tried to shut down.

articles.headline: A Cliffhanger to See if a G.M. Turnaround Succeeds
articles.snippet: Executives worked for months and taxpayers poured in $50 billion. The payoff, however, remains unclear.
articles.abstract: Executives worked for months and taxpayers poured in $50 billion. The payoff, however, remains unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: SATURDAY, May 30, offered the kind of warm, sunny afternoon that rain-soaked New Yorkers had longed for all spring. In the theater district, crowds were gathering to catch a glimpse of Barack and Michelle Obama, who were planning to attend a Broadway show so the president could fulfill his campaign promise to his wife of a date night in Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: For Mozilla and Google, Group Hugs Get Tricky
articles.snippet: Mozilla’s open-source Firefox browser now faces competition from a gigantic longtime partner.
articles.abstract: Mozilla’s open-source Firefox browser now faces competition from a gigantic longtime partner.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.

articles.headline: Benchmarks as Bendable as Gumby
articles.snippet: A creative definition of “cash earnings” at a company that offers performance-based stock awards.
articles.abstract: A creative definition of “cash earnings” at a company that offers performance-based stock awards.
articles.lead_paragraph: SELF-SERVING compensation practices, we can now agree, played a central role in the financial wreckage that still surrounds us. For example, rewarding Wall Street’s outsized risk-takers with immediate bonuses, no matter how their trades worked out, turned out to be, well, disastrous.

articles.headline: ‘Nightline’ Is Thriving in Late Night
articles.snippet: While two talk shows scrap for viewers, a news program makes gains and, on its best nights, comes out on top.
articles.abstract: While two talk shows scrap for viewers, a news program makes gains and, on its best nights, comes out on top.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the heavyweight battle being waged in late-night television, an awful lot of rounds lately have been going to a third man in the ring, the one not slugging it out with punch lines.

articles.headline: Site Wins Fashion Fans by Letting Them Design
articles.snippet: A fashion site is winning fans by allowing users to build collages with photos of clothing, accessories and models.
articles.abstract: A fashion site is winning fans by allowing users to build collages with photos of clothing, accessories and models.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  The fashion magazines Vogue, InStyle and Lucky may rule the newsstand racks. But online, they are also-rans, overlooked by the fashion-conscious in favor of Polyvore, an upstart Web site far from Fifth Avenue.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Seek to Curb Drug Commercials
articles.snippet: Critics say the ads take advantage of hypochondriacs, lead people to pressure doctors for prescriptions, overstate benefits and understate risks.
articles.abstract: Critics say the ads take advantage of hypochondriacs, lead people to pressure doctors for prescriptions, overstate benefits and understate risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, Nancy Reagan told Americans to “Just Say No” to recreational drugs.

articles.headline: In West Bank Settlements, Sign of Hope for a Deal
articles.snippet: Two growing ultra-Orthodox settlements offer the surprising potential for Israeli compromise with the Palestinians.
articles.abstract: Two growing ultra-Orthodox settlements offer the surprising potential for Israeli compromise with the Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: MODIIN ILLIT, West Bank  Seen from afar, this fast-growing settlement embodies everything that the Obama administration wants to address through its demand for a freeze on settlement building: it sits on land captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war and, with 45,000 residents and 60 births a week, it is the largest and fastest-growing Jewish community in the West Bank.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: IPhone Maker in China Is Under Fire After a Suicide
articles.snippet: A 25-year-old worker in China jumped from an apartment building after being accused of stealing an iPhone prototype.
articles.abstract: A 25-year-old worker in China jumped from an apartment building after being accused of stealing an iPhone prototype.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China  When a closely guarded prototype of a new Apple iPhone went missing at a huge factory here two weeks ago, an internal investigation focused on a shy, 25-year-old employee named Sun Danyong.

articles.headline: Lab Watches Web Surfers to See Which Ads Work
articles.snippet: Companies want to know more about the millions who do not click on ads, but whose eyes merely flit across the screen.
articles.abstract: Companies want to know more about the millions who do not click on ads, but whose eyes merely flit across the screen.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.  A technician in a black lab coat gazed at the short, middle-aged man seated inside the Walt Disney Company’s secretive new research facility here last week, his face shrouded with eye-tracking goggles. Read ESPN.com on that BlackBerry, she told him soothingly, like a nurse about to draw blood. “And have fun,” she added, leaving the room.

articles.headline: Forget Aloof, Bernanke Goes Barnstorming
articles.snippet: The chairman of the Federal Reserve is on a publicity campaign to prove that the central bank is here to help.
articles.abstract: The chairman of the Federal Reserve is on a publicity campaign to prove that the central bank is here to help.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is on a publicity campaign with a message: the central bank is here to help, and it is not as mysterious or menacing as people might think.

articles.headline: Files Vanished, Young Chinese Lose the Future
articles.snippet: Officials are suspected of stealing academic records and selling them to underachievers seeking better prospects.
articles.abstract: Officials are suspected of stealing academic records and selling them to underachievers seeking better prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUBU, China  For much of his education, Xue Longlong was silently accompanied from grade to grade, school to school, by a sealed Manila envelope stamped top secret. Stuffed inside were grades, test results, evaluations by fellow students and teachers, his Communist Party application and  most important for his job prospects  proof of his 2006 college degree.
